TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, frigid Typic Haplustalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Boyett sandy loam-forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
0i--1 inch to 0; needles, leaves, and twigs.
A--0 to 5 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/2) sandy loam; dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable; 5 percent pebbles; few fine and medium roots, few fine interstitial pores; slightly acid (pH 6.2); clear smooth boundary.  (3 to 6 inches thick)
E--5 to 9 inches; pink (7.5YR 7/4) gravelly coarse sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak medium and fine granular structure; slightly hard, friable; 15 percent pebbles; few fine and medium roots; common fine tubular pores; slightly acid (pH 6.4); abrupt wavy boundary.  (3 to 8 inches thick)
Bt1--9 to 16 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) gravelly sandy loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium angular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, slightly sticky, and slightly plastic; 20 percent pebbles; few very fine roots; slightly acid (pH 6.2); abrupt smooth boundary.  (6 to 12 inches thick)
Bt2--16 to 34 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) gravelly sandy loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/3) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, sticky, and plastic; 30 percent pebbles; few very fine roots; slightly acid (pH 6.3); abrupt smooth boundary.  (14 to 22 inches thick)
Btk--34 to 42 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) gravelly sandy loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/3) moist; weak medium prismatic structure parting to weak medium subangular blocky; very hard, firm, sticky; 15 percent lime coated pebbles; violently effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); gradual smooth boundary.  (6 to 12 inches thick)
Ck--42 to 53 inches; light reddish brown (5YR 6/4) sandy loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, sticky; 5 percent lime coated pebbles; violently effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4).
R--53 inches; arkosic sandstone.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Teller County, Colorado; in the center of the west half of Sec. 15, T. 11 S., R. 69 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Calcium carbonate equivalent and exchangeable sodium is less than two percent throughout the soil.  Base saturation ranges from 82 to 100 percent in the argillic horizon.  Rock fragments range from 5 to 35 percent by volume and are mainly less than 2 inches in diameter.  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 44 to 46 degrees F. and the mean annual summer soil temperature ranges from 59 to 66 degrees F.  Carbonates range in depth from 26 to 48 inches.
The A horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 4 to 5 dry, 3 or 4 moist, and chroma or 1 or 2.  The upper 7 inches when mixed has moist mollic colors.  Reaction is slightly acid.
The E horizon has hue of 7.5YR through 5YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  Reaction is slightly acid.
The Bt horizon has hue of 7.5YR through 2.5YR, value of 4 or 5 dry, 3 or 4 moist, and chroma of 3 through 6.  Reaction is slightly acid in the upper part to moderately alkaline in the lower part.  Clay ranges from 12 to 18 percent.
The C horizon has hue of 10YR through 2.5YR, value of 4 through 7 dry, 3 through 6 moist, and chroma of 4 through 6.  It is typically loam, sandy loam, or coarse sand.  It is mildly or moderately alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Holdingford (mn) and Rockwood (mn) series.  The Holdingford and Rockwood soils lack an arkosic influence in the Bt horizon and are more friable.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Boyett soils are on alluvial terraces,  hills and ridges.  Slopes range from 2 to 40 percent.  The soil formed in parent materials locally transported from sedimentary arkosic beds of the Fountain and Lyons Formations or in red aeolian material over sandstone.  At the type location the average annual precipitation is 15 to 20 inches.  Mean annual temperature ranges from 42 to 44 degrees F, and the summer temperature ranges 58 to 64 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Frenchcreek, Perrypark, Paunsaugunt, and Sphinx soils.  The Frenchcreek and Perrypark soils are on alluvial terraces and fans.  The Paunsaugunt soils are underlain by limestone at a shallow depth.  The Sphinx soils are shallow and occur on steeper uplands.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to slow runoff; moderate to moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for forestry, pastureland, recreation, and watershed.  Native vegetation is mainly ponderosa pine, oak brush, and an understory of grasses.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  The foothill areas along the front range of central Colorado.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Teller County, (Pike National Forest-East part-Soil Survey Area) Colorado, 1984.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic features include a mollic intergrade epipedon from 0 to 5 inches and an argillic horizon from 9 to 42 inches.  Last updated by the state 7/91.  The name is from a Creek in the area.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
